articles.headline: Approach Boss With Caution
articles.snippet: If the personality of Jonathan G. Ornstein, head of the Mesa Air Group, is outsize, so are his ambitions. He wants to make the regional airline global.
articles.abstract: If the personality of Jonathan G. Ornstein, head of the Mesa Air Group, is outsize, so are his ambitions. He wants to make the regional airline global.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — On a scale of one to 10, with 10 being the most volatile personality, Jonathan G. Ornstein, chief executive of the Mesa Air Group, cheerfully admitted, “I used to be an 11.”

articles.headline: Flexing Muscle, China Destroys Satellite in Test
articles.snippet: The successful test of an antisatellite weapon signals China’s resolve to play a major role in military space activities.
articles.abstract: The successful test of an antisatellite weapon signals China’s resolve to play a major role in military space activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: China successfully carried out its first test of an antisatellite weapon last week, signaling its resolve to play a major role in military space activities and bringing expressions of concern from Washington and other capitals, the Bush administration said yesterday.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: A Coalition for Firm Limit on Emissions
articles.snippet: Ten companies have banded with environmental groups to call for a nationwide cap on carbon dioxide emissions.
articles.abstract: Ten companies have banded with environmental groups to call for a nationwide cap on carbon dioxide emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — Ten major companies with operations across the economy — utilities, manufacturing, petroleum, chemicals and financial services — have banded together with leading environmental groups to call for a firm nationwide limit on carbon dioxide emissions that would lead to reductions of 10 to 30 percent over the next 15 years.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Warns That Entitlement Growth Could Harm Economy
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke warned of the long-term danger posed by looming deficits in Social Security and Medicare.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke warned of the long-term danger posed by looming deficits in Social Security and Medicare.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — Warning against complacency over the federal deficit, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Thursday that recent positive trends on the budget were a “calm before the storm,” masking a long-term danger posed by looming deficits in Social Security and Medicare.

articles.headline: Rebuke in Iran to Its President on Nuclear Role
articles.snippet: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad may be under pressure from Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
articles.abstract: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad may be under pressure from Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
articles.byline: By Nazila Fathi and Michael Slackman

articles.headline: Wall Street Is Betting on the Farm
articles.snippet: Wall Street commodity funds that have been investing heavily in energy futures are now loading up on agricultural commodities like corn and livestock futures.
articles.abstract: Wall Street commodity funds that have been investing heavily in energy futures are now loading up on agricultural commodities like corn and livestock futures.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 18 — Wall Street commodity funds that have been investing heavily in energy futures are now loading up on agricultural commodities like corn and livestock futures.
articles.byline: By Alexei Barrionuevo and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: House Votes to Rescind Oil Drillers’ Tax Breaks
articles.snippet: The legislation would rescind $14 billion in tax breaks and reserve the money to develop alternative energy projects.
articles.abstract: The legislation would rescind $14 billion in tax breaks and reserve the money to develop alternative energy projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — House Democrats easily passed legislation on Thursday that would rescind $14 billion in tax breaks and subsidies for oil drillers and reserve the money to develop alternative energy projects and conservation technologies.
